page.title: 01THE AREA
page.content: The 12km area is of chalk downland of the cretaceous period under lain by clays. The soil is derived from the weathered residue of the chalk,a clay_ with_flints mixture. This gives rise to a calcemorphic brown earth. The area has a general trend to the south west and the cliffs. Surface drainage is at present for the most part absent but there is evidence in the landscpe of a past drainage pattern,now seen only as a series of small dry_valleys. Many of the small farmsteads have occupied these re_entrant areas. One would suggest this would be due to the collection of water in the areas in a time of increased rainfall. The settlements,many of the very old,are of a nodal patten with little ribbon development except in the large villages Employment is mainly associated with the docks in Dover.
